ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic keyboard knowledge, how to stray away from just playing the chords right off the page, more about improvisation
I learned how to read figured bass, add bass lines to melodies, write melody harmonizations, and do some improv. I improved a lot at reading music for keyboard.
Chord functions, harmonizing a melody, playing from figured bass, and playing from jazz lead sheets.
Learned many practical skills at the piano including harmonizing melodies, accompanying both jazz and classical style playing, score reading, chord replacement, among other things.
Learned how to read scores in figured bass, roman numeral analysis/chord functions, melody harmonization, accompaniment for figured bass scores
Fundamentals of figured bass, lead sheet improvisation, melody harmonization. Extremely useful for developing piano skills, regardless of your previous experience.
I learned how to harmonize melodies, read jazz lead sheets, and realize figured bass on the keyboard. I also learned how to analyze chord progressions with roman numeral analysis.
Figured bass realization, melody harmonization, generally improving in my piano-playing ability
knowledge and practice for reading lead sheets and figured bass, composing harmonizations, and other keyboard skills

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There is room to learn at your own pace, no matter your background on piano. I would recommend completing at least one music theory course before taking this one, because many concepts are already assumed you know.

Strengths: covers very practical and interesting topics like melody harmonization; good level of workload; content is well organized and the learning curve is just right; both instructors are very encouraging and helpful when giving feedback.
Course should be offered as a full credit, and I wish there was more access to individual time.
Strengths: great instructor, great TA, excellent examples and assignments. The only weakness was not getting feedback on any of the recorded assignments.

While fundamental music theory knowledge is required, the course reviews a majority of the topics before assuming that everyone is familiar with the more advanced terms. I was able to get very personalized feedback and recommendations for improving my skills on the keyboard, which is one of the main reasons I enjoyed this class so much.

This course is fantastic. I thought the curriculum met people from several different musical backgrounds where they were at very well, and the choices of classical and jazz/pop were good. I think there could have been a few more options for advanced study / next steps, such as jazz harmonization or playing in different genres (and also giving more intermediate players a taste of the possibilities).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because it's class that requires a piano, the class could be inaccessible to anyone who doesn't have one. Otherwise the class had a good set up, where lectures were live and you could practice concepts (muted) on your own as they're introduced. Meetings with the professor or TA and another student were also very helpful for asking questions and seeing if your playing is right before an assignment is due.
Small group meetings were really helpful.
There was a lot of dead air time because professors felt like engaging the class by asking questions. this is also typical of music classes at yale and I don't really think it's that necessary.
The piano cameras were very useful in learning how to properly implement techniques and which chords were correct. For example, inversions were easy to understand with the visual assistance.

The small group sessions to go over what we practiced were very effective. Lectures, slides, and sound-sharing all worked great. Unfortunately we couldn't learn much about improvisation or playing live with others but that's pretty much impossible to teach virtually

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! You'll really improve at keyboard and reading music, especially if you're a beginner. The assignments will take time, though, so you'll need to set aside time to practice.
Yes! It was very exciting to learn to harmonize melodies. I would recommend it to all piano players.
Yes, you will improve your skills at the piano if you put in the time and engage with the class.
Yes absolutely, even (especially?) if you don't consider yourself a pianist
Yes, just make sure that you meet the majority of the prerequisites. Without my (minimal) previous knowledge in music theory, I would have struggled much more.

The course is good if you are interested in learning about both the classical side with figured bass and melody harmonization as well as the pop/jazz side of keyboard harmony. If you are not interested in one of these topics, or if you already have a lot of experience with either, you will most likely be bored since a lot of time is spent covering both. The course mostly stays at the beginner/introductory level and we didn't explore many advanced topics.

Definitely take this course if you're interested in music theory and want an enhanced visual and tactile understanding from the piano, as well as some foundational skills that will go a long way towards playing things

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture and virtual small group meetings.
we would also have live individual and group sessions where we were given tips on our playing.
Small group/individual performances
small group meetings with a few students to present our progress
